Caption: Fig. 1. Two viewers analyzing data visualizations from different viewpoints in front of a large high-resolution wall display (a). A participant conducting a trial during our first experiment (b).
Fig. 2. Two observers looking at the same angles, lengths, and circles displayed across a large wall display.
Fig. 3. Calculations of visual angles θ and viewer-object distance v (in cm) on our wall display. We tested screens with red borders in our study.

Fig. 5. Example screens showing the large interactive stimulus (green) the viewers adjusted to match the remote modulus (red) for Length, Area and Angle. The stimulus was always close to the participant’s location.

Values per screen indi- cate the percentage difference in average judgments for this modulus location. Values > 100% are overestimations and values < 100% under- estimations. Table 1. Regression analysis coefficients C. For our setup the perceived size can be predicted using the following equation PerMag = Constant + Cmt ∗ mt +CDistance ∗ Distance +CscreenX ∗ ScreenX +CscreenY ∗ ScreenY .
